She began her career in show business as a model and later transitioned to acting, appearing in numerous stage productions and eventually landing a contract with MGM Studios.

Kelly's breakthrough role came in 1954 with the film "The Country Girl," for which she received an Academy Award nomination for Best Actress. She went on to star in a string of successful films, including "Rear Window" (1954), "To Catch a Thief" (1955), and "High Society" (1956).

As princess, Kelly devoted herself to her charitable work and philanthropic efforts, particularly in the area of education. She founded the Princess Grace Foundation, which supported students and artists in the United States and Europe. She also worked tirelessly to promote the cultural and economic development of Monaco.

Kelly's life was cut short in a car accident on September 13, 1982, while driving in the French Riviera. She was just 52 years old. Her legacy lives on through her iconic films, her philanthropic work, and her enduring influence on fashion and style.

Kelly's personal style, characterized by her elegant sense of fashion and her signature bouffant hairstyle, continues to inspire designers and fashion enthusiasts to this day. She remains one of the most beloved and enduring Hollywood legends of all time.
